msDesc.head: Maktūbāt-i ʻAbd al-Quddūs by Khiz̤r Jawnpūrī

msContents.summary: Maktūbāt-i ʻAbd al-Quddūs, a collection of letters of the famous Indian saint ʻAbd al-Quddūs ibn Ismāʻīl Ḥanafī Gangūhī, compiled by his disciple Khiz̤r Budhan Ṣiddīqī of Jawnpūr, called Miyān Khān ibn Qivām al-Mulk (f. 3b).

author.persName: Khiz̤r Budhan Ṣiddīqī Jawnpūrī, known as Mīyān Khān ibn Qivām al-Mulk
خضر بدهن صدیقی جونپوری مشهور به میان خان ابن قوام الملک

msItem.title: Maktūbāt-i ʻAbd al-Quddūs
مکتوبات عبد القدوس
msItem.incipit: حمد بیحد مر خدای را که دلهای عارفان را مخزن اسرار خود گردانیده و جانهای دوستان را مظهر عشق و محبت خود ساخت و به نور ذکر دلهای ایشان منور گردانید تا نام اغیار بر لسان ایشان جاری نگردد
msItem.explicit: مدتی مدید گذشته است که اخبار نرسیده است موانع به خیر باد و بالنبی و آله الامجاد
msItem.colophon: تمت تمام شد کار من نظام شد کار من به کام

note.p: Folios 1v-5v contain a table of contents listing 168 letters (maktūbāt) and their correspondents, whereas there are in fact 193 letters. A note on f. 6r states that there are 6 folios of contents, which suggests that one folio is missing after folio 5.
The last letter (f. 241r) seems unfinished and stops suddenly, suggesting the work is incomplete at the end.

foliation.p: India Office stamped foliation. Also foliated with Persian numerals which do not correspond.

condition.p: Worm-eaten. Remargined, gauzed and rebound by India Office Library.

handNote.p: Nastaʻlīq, copied in black ink, with headings, ovelinings and punctuation marks in red.

decoDesc.decoNote: Margins ruled in red and blue. Outer frame ruled in blue.

additions.p: F. 1r contains a prayer for when a snake bites someone, and two notes stating the number of folios.
F. 6r contains another note counting the folios and a note on how to arrange the folios in the correct order.

binding.decoNote: Half-leather red India Office Library binding stamped 8 February 1936.

seal.p: Black circular seal of ʻAbd al-Rafīʻ, servant of the court of ʻĀlamgīr (bandah-i dargāh-i Ālamgīr Pādshāh Ghāzī), date illegible (f. 6r).
Black Government of India Delhi MSS oval stamp (ff. 1r, 241v).

provenance.p: Belonged to ʻAbd al-Rafīʻ, a court official of the Mughal emperor Aurangzib ʻĀlamgīr (r.1658-1707).
Purchased by the Government of India at sale organised by Delhi Prize Agents, 1859.

acquisition.p: Acquired by the India Office Library as an administrative deposit in 1876.

source.p: Based on A.J. Arberry's description in Drafts for Catalogue of Persian Manuscripts in the India Office Library, vol. III, Mss Eur E207/3, f. 16r and R. Levy's description in the same work,Mss Eur E207/13, f. 75r. Revised by Sheida Heydarishovir
